elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A series of coordination polymers, namely, [Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1), [Cd(L)(HIP)]⋅1/2H2O (2), [Co1.5(L)(BTC)(CH3OH)(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (3), [Ni1.5(L)(BTC)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O (4), where L=2-4-(Chloro-phenoxy)-N-pyridin-3-yl-acetamide, H2HIP=5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complexes 1, 3 and 4 display 1D chain structure. In complex 2, each Cd2 unit is linked into BTC form two dimensional layer structures, which are further connected by μ2-L ligand to construct 3D architecture with {424;64}-bcu topology.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A series of coordination polymers, namely, [Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1), [Cd(L)(HIP)]⋅1/2H2O (2), [Co1.5(L)(BTC)(CH3OH)(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (3), [Ni1.5(L)(BTC)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O (4), where L=2-(4-Chloro-phenoxy)-N-pyridin-3-ylacetamide, H2HIP=5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complexes 1, 3 and 4 display 1D chain structure. In complex 2, each Cd2 unit is linked into BTC form two dimensional layer structures, which are further connected by μ 2-L ligand to construct 3D architecture with {424;64}-bcu topology. Moreover, their powder X-ray diffraction analysis, thermostability and luminescence properties are explored.

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The construction of coordination polymers has attracted considerable interest during the past decades not only due to their intriguing network topologies but also their potential applications in catalysis , luminescence , magnetism , gas adsorption , electrochemistry . A large number of studies showed the synthesis of coordination frame works depend on reaction temperature, pH, reactants molar ratio, central metal ion and the nature of organic ligands . Especially, properties of organic ligands, such as angle, distance, flexibility and functional groups are the key factors for the synthesis of coordination polymers . Therefore, utilizing multidentate organic ligands including N or O donors is considered to be an effective strategy to form coordination polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of coordination polymers has attracted considerable interest during the past decades not only due to their intriguing network topologies but also their potential applications in catalysis , luminescence , magnetism , gas adsorption , electrochemistry . A large number of studies showed the synthesis of coordination frame works depend on reaction temperature, pH, reactants molar ratio, central metal ion and the nature of organic ligands . Especially, properties of organic ligands, such as angle, distance, flexibility and functional groups are the key factors for the synthesis of coordination polymers . Therefore, utilizing multidentate organic ligands including N or O donors is considered to be an effective strategy to form coordination polymers .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Acylamide functional ligands as N-donor ligands have been received widespread attention because not only their has the abilities to provide two types of hydrogen bonding sites, the −NH moiety acting as an electron acceptor and the −C=O group acting as an electron donor, which is contribute to the construction of supramolecular structure but also obtained product has a potential biological activity . The study of amide complexes including mono-pyridyl-mono-amide , pyridyl mono-amide , bis-pyridyl-bis-amide  and tripyridyl tri-amide  has attracted much attentions in recent years.</ce:para>

The study of amide complexes including mono-pyridyl-mono-amide , pyridyl mono-amide , bis-pyridyl-bis-amide  and tripyridyl tri-amide  has attracted much attentions in recent years.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Multicarboxylate ligands as multidentate O-donor ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic (1,3,5-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC) are often selected as multifunctional organic linkers to form the structures of higher dimensions because of their abundant coordination modes and strong coordination ability . A great number of 1D-, 2D-, 3D-framework, constructed by combining the carboxylate ligands and N-donor ligands under hydrothermal conditions, were reported . For example, Wang’s group reported a series bis-pyridyl-bis-amide coordination polymers and their properties including luminescence, electrochemistry and photocatalytic properties in recent years .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Multicarboxylate ligands as multidentate O-donor ligands such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2BDC), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic (1,3,5-H3BTC) are often selected as multifunctional organic linkers to form the structures of higher dimensions because of their abundant coordination modes and strong coordination ability . A great number of 1D-, 2D-, 3D-framework, constructed by combining the carboxylate ligands and N-donor ligands under hydrothermal conditions, were reported . For example, Wang's group reported a series bis-pyridyl-bis-amide coordination polymers and their properties including luminescence, electrochemistry and photocatalytic properties in recent years .

elements.clean_text: In this study, we chose the 2-(4-Chloro-phenoxy)-N-pyridin-3-ylacetamide (L) ( ) and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H2HIP), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) ( ) as mixed ligands to react with the transition metal salts and as a result, four new complexes [Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1), [Cd(L)(HIP)]⋅1/2H2O (2), [Co1.5(L)(BTC)(CH3OH)(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (3), [Ni1.5(L)(BTC)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O (4). Their solid state structures, powder X-ray diffraction analysis, thermal stability and luminescent properties have been studied.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and physical measurements

All the reagents and the solvents were purchased commercially and were used directly without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was carried out on Perkin-Elmer 2400II elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectrometer fourier transform infrared spectroscopy in the 4000-400cm-1 regions, using KBr pellets. Perkin-Elmer Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer was used under air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10Kmin-1 in the temperature range 30-800°C using platinum crucibles. Fluorescence spectra were recorded with F-2500 FL Spectrophotometer analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained by using a pinhole camera (Anton Paar) operating with a point focused Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range from 5° to 50° with a scan rate of 0.08° per second.

Synthesis of [Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297g, 0.1mmol), L (0.0263g, 0.1mmol), H2HIP (0.0182g, 0.1mmol), H2O (10mL), and NaOH (0.010g, 0.25mmol) were placed in a 25mL teflon reactor. The mixture was heated at 120°C for 3days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting orange crystalline materials were collected. Yield: 42% (based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C21H17ClN2O8Zn: C, 47.89; H, 3.23; N, 5.32. Found: C, 47.87; H, 3.21; N, 5.35%. IR (cm-1): 3382 (s), 3256 (s), 3065 (s), 1706 (m), 1629 (m), 1600 (w), 1566 (s), 1489 (s), 1446 (w), 1416 (m), 1364 (m), 1334 (m), 1311 (w), 1292 (w), 1243 (w), 1224 (m), 1127 (w), 1089 (m), 1003 (m), 820 (w), 782 (m), 735 (m) 665 (w).

X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals with approximate dimensions were mounted on a glass fiber and used for X-ray diffraction analyses. The data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer at 293(2)K. Using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71069Å). Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized position and refined using a riding model. The crystallographic data as well as details of the data collection and refinement for the complex are listed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in  , and possible hydrogen bond geometries are given  .

Results and discussion

Description of crystal structures

[Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallized in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The crystal structure of complex 1 contains a Zn(II) ion, one L ligand and two HIP anions and one coordinated water. As shown in  a, each Zn(II) ion adopts a distorted {ZnNO3} tetrahedral geometry to coordinate with one nitrogen atom from one L ligand with a Zn-N2 distance of 2.047(3) Å, Three oxygen atoms from the two HIP ligands and one coordinated water molecule, with the Zn-O distances of 1.952(3) Å, 2.000(3) Å and 2.011(3) Å, respectively. In 1, the HIP anion shows a similar "V" shaped bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode to connect the adjacent Zn(II) ions to form a chain with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 9.467(5) Å. The adjacent 1D chains are also linked together by the hydrogen bonding interaction between the oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules and HIP [O(8)-H(8A)⋯O(2)#4], this forms a ladder-like 2D supramolecular net (b). The final 3D supramolecular framework of 1 is constructed through the hydrogen bonding interactions (O(8)-H(8B)⋯O(7)#3=2.649(4) Å, N(1)-H(1)⋯O(3)#3=2.851(4) Å, O(5)-H(5)⋯O(4)#5=2.800(4) Å) (c).

The coordination environment of Cd(II) ion is depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a. The Cd(II) ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms [Cd(1)–O, 2.2086(17)–2.4537(18) Å] from three HIP ligands, which occupy equatorial positions and one nitrogen atom (N2A) as well as oxygen atom (O6) from two L ligands [Cd(1)–N(2)#3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.311(2) Å, Cd(1)–O(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.451(2) Å], which belong to axial positions, this constructs a six-coordinated octahedron environment. As for the HIP ligands, all the hydroxyl groups do not participate in the coordination with Cd(II) ions but the two carboxylate groups of the HIP ligands adopt different coordination fashion to connect Cd(II) ions. One carboxylate group connects to Cd(II) ion, and another carboxylate group adopts a chelate/bridge tridentate coordination mode connecting two Cd(II) ions (b). Two Cd(II) ions are linked by two chelate/bridge carboxylate groups from two HIP to form a Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 3.738<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Different Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units are connected by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-HIP resulting in a 2D layer with 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-<ce:bold>sql</ce:bold>. Different 2D layers are linked by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-L ligands to form a 3D architecture (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Cd(L)(HIP)]⋅1/2H2O (2)

Single crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 2 is a 3D metal -organic coordination polymer. The coordination environment of Cd(II) ion is depicted in  a. The Cd(II) ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms [Cd(1)-O, 2.2086(17)-2.4537(18) Å] from three HIP ligands, which occupy equatorial positions and one nitrogen atom (N2A) as well as oxygen atom (O6) from two L ligands [Cd(1)-N(2)#3=2.311(2) Å, Cd(1)-O(6)=2.451(2) Å], which belong to axial positions, this constructs a six-coordinated octahedron environment. As for the HIP ligands, all the hydroxyl groups do not participate in the coordination with Cd(II) ions but the two carboxylate groups of the HIP ligands adopt different coordination fashion to connect Cd(II) ions. One carboxylate group connects to Cd(II) ion, and another carboxylate group adopts a chelate/bridge tridentate coordination mode connecting two Cd(II) ions (b). Two Cd(II) ions are linked by two chelate/bridge carboxylate groups from two HIP to form a Cd2 unit with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 3.738Å. Different Cd2 units are connected by μ2-HIP resulting in a 2D layer with 44-sql. Different 2D layers are linked by μ2-L ligands to form a 3D architecture (c).

[Co1.5(L)(BTC)(CH3OH)(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (3) and [Ni1.5(L)(BTC)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O (4)

Complex 4 shows a similar coordination environment as complex 3. Complex 3 contains one coordinated methanol molecule and there is one coordinated water molecule on the structure of complex 4. complex 3 and complex 4 crystallize in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one and a half Co(II) atoms, one L ligand, one BTC ligand, three coordinated water molecules, one coordinated methanol molecule and two lattice water molecules. As show in  a, there are two crystallographically independent Co(II) centers with different coordination environments, the Co1(II) is six-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from carboxyl groups of two BTC ligands in the apical positions and four coordinated water molecules in the equatorial positions showing a CoO6 distorted octahedral environment. The Co2(II) is surrounded by four oxygen atoms of one carboxyl group from one BTC ligand, one coordinated methanol molecule and one coordinated water molecule as well as one nitrogen atom from L. In 3, the BTC ligands adopt a μ3-bridging mode connect with three Co(II) ions to generate a ladder-like chain with the Co1(II) on the rungs (Co1⋯Co1 10.352Å), and the Co2(II) on the siderails (Co2⋯Co2 10.352Å). The ladder-like chain are further connected by hydrogen bonding interaction (O(2W)-H(2W1)⋯O(8)#5), resulting in a 2D network of complex 3 (b). Finally, coordinated water molecules connect the adjacent layers into 3D supramolecular framework by hydrogen bonding interactions (O(2W)-H(2W2)⋯O(3)#4, O(2W)-H(2W1)⋯O(8)#5) (c).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">Discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st753">IR spectrum</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The strong peaks at 1629 and 1334<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 1609 and 1380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 1610 and 1372<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 1611 and 1369<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, may be attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of carboxyl groups. The bands around 1706<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 1669<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 1668<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 1666<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, are characteristic of the carbonyl groups. The presence of the characteristic bands at 1566, 1489, 1446, 1364<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 1541, 1488, 1442, 1421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 1547, 1489, 1460, 1431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 1548, 1489, 1461, 1430<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, suggest the stretching vibrations of the pyridyl rings the organic ligands. The bands at 3382 3440 3286 3384 are assigned to stretching and bending vibrations of <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>OH groups of water molecules for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

IR spectrum

The strong peaks at 1629 and 1334cm-1 for 1, 1609 and 1380cm-1 for 2, 1610 and 1372cm-1 for 3, 1611 and 1369cm-1 for 4, may be attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of carboxyl groups. The bands around 1706cm-1 for 1 and 1669cm-1 for 2, 1668cm-1 for 3, 1666cm-1 for 4, are characteristic of the carbonyl groups. The presence of the characteristic bands at 1566, 1489, 1446, 1364cm-1 for 1, 1541, 1488, 1442, 1421cm-1 for 2, 1547, 1489, 1460, 1431cm-1 for 3, 1548, 1489, 1461, 1430cm-1 for 4, suggest the stretching vibrations of the pyridyl rings the organic ligands. The bands at 3382 3440 3286 3384 are assigned to stretching and bending vibrations of OH groups of water molecules for complex 1-4.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>271<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). Thus, compared to L, the emission maxima of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are red-shifted. The most likely emission mechanism is ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The fluorescent intensity of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stronger than that of the free ligand, because of the ligand coordinated to the metal center, which enhances its rigidity and thus reduces the loss of energy through radiationless pathways . The strong fluorescence emission of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a potential application value in photosensitive material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties

The samples for solid-state luminescence of complexes 1-2 and the free ligand L have been investigated at room temperature because of their potential photoactive applications . As show in  , the L ligand displays an emission band at 312nm (λ ex =276nm), which may be ascribed to the π → π ∗ or n → π ∗ transitions . Under the same excitation conditions, the complex 1 displays a broad and strong emission at 368nm upon excitation at 273nm. For complex 2, it can be observed that emission occurs at 344nm (λ ex =271nm). Thus, compared to L, the emission maxima of 1 and 2 are red-shifted. The most likely emission mechanism is ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The fluorescent intensity of complex 1 is stronger than that of the free ligand, because of the ligand coordinated to the metal center, which enhances its rigidity and thus reduces the loss of energy through radiationless pathways . The strong fluorescence emission of complex 1 shows a potential application value in photosensitive material.

<ce:section-title id="st080">Thermogravimetric analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of coordination complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> investigated to exhibit their thermal stabilities. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the test for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are carried out at temperature range from 30 to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under an air atmosphere, For 1, the first weight loss, 5.08%, at 130–175<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is ascribed to a loss of coordinated water molecules (Calc. 3.42%). The overall framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> begins to collapse at 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ends 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with the ZnO residue of 16.13% (Calc.: 15.47%). A first weight loss of 2.11% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at a region of 140–280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the elimination of the one water molecule (Calc.: 1.60%). The second stage occurs between 350 and 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and corresponds to the release of the organic ligand. The corresponding weight losses are 75.28% (Calc. 75.64%). After 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is no further weight loss. The residues (22.61%) is CdO (Calc. 22.76%). For complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the first weight loss step from 90 to 210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is attributed to the loss of the lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules and methanol molecules. The weight loss is about 17.20% (Calc. 17.94%). A second weight loss was observed in a range of 210–550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the decomposition of organic ligands L and BTC. The CoO residue of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> of 17.73% (Calc.: 16.52%). The TG curves of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit two obvious weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 14.72% at temperatures between 80 and 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is assigned to the elimination of the water molecules and coordinated waters (Calc.: 17.76%). The second weight loss occurred at 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The NiO residue of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is 16.68% (Calc.: 16.38%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of coordination complexes 1-4 investigated to exhibit their thermal stabilities. As shown in  , the test for complexes 1-4 are carried out at temperature range from 30 to 800°C under an air atmosphere, For 1, the first weight loss, 5.08%, at 130-175°C is ascribed to a loss of coordinated water molecules (Calc. 3.42%). The overall framework of 1 begins to collapse at 280°C and ends 600°C with the ZnO residue of 16.13% (Calc.: 15.47%). A first weight loss of 2.11% for 2 at a region of 140-280°C is equivalent to the elimination of the one water molecule (Calc.: 1.60%). The second stage occurs between 350 and 520°C and corresponds to the release of the organic ligand. The corresponding weight losses are 75.28% (Calc. 75.64%). After 520°C, there is no further weight loss. The residues (22.61%) is CdO (Calc. 22.76%). For complex 3, the first weight loss step from 90 to 210°C is attributed to the loss of the lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules and methanol molecules. The weight loss is about 17.20% (Calc. 17.94%). A second weight loss was observed in a range of 210-550°C, corresponding to the decomposition of organic ligands L and BTC. The CoO residue of 3 of 17.73% (Calc.: 16.52%). The TG curves of complex 4 exhibit two obvious weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 14.72% at temperatures between 80 and 200°C is assigned to the elimination of the water molecules and coordinated waters (Calc.: 17.76%). The second weight loss occurred at 270°C. The NiO residue of 4 is 16.68% (Calc.: 16.38%).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st090">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">In summary, a series of mono-pyridyl-mono-amide coordination polymers were prepared under solvothermal conditions and were characterized by IR spectrum, elemental analysis, fluorescent properties, thermogravimetric analysis and Powder X-ray diffraction patterns analysis. The title complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> display 1-D coordinated polymer while complex 2 displays 3-D mof structure. The results show that mono-pyridyl-mono-amide is a good candidate for construction coordination polymers with stable and intriguing structures. Moreover, the polycarboxylates also greatly contribute to the structural diversities of the final frameworks. The fluorescent behaviors <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> imply that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be good candidates for photoactive materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a series of mono-pyridyl-mono-amide coordination polymers were prepared under solvothermal conditions and were characterized by IR spectrum, elemental analysis, fluorescent properties, thermogravimetric analysis and Powder X-ray diffraction patterns analysis. The title complexes 1, 3, 4 display 1-D coordinated polymer while complex 2 displays 3-D mof structure. The results show that mono-pyridyl-mono-amide is a good candidate for construction coordination polymers with stable and intriguing structures. Moreover, the polycarboxylates also greatly contribute to the structural diversities of the final frameworks. The fluorescent behaviors 1-2 imply that complexes 1 may be good candidates for photoactive materials.

Preparations

Synthesis of L

The L ligand was prepared according to the literature method . Elemental Anal. Calc. for C13H11ClN2O2: C, 59.39; H, 4.19; N, 10.66. Found: C, 59.37; H, 4.20; N, 10.67%. IR (cm-1): 3445 (s), 1684 (s), 1650 (m), 1592 (m), 1537 (s), 1508 (w), 1489 (s), 1434 (m), 1408 (m), 1284 (m), 1235 (s), 1172 (w), 1089 (w), 1067 (m), 822 (m), 710 (m), 664 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn(L)(HIP)(H2O)] (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297g, 0.1mmol), L (0.0263g, 0.1mmol), H2HIP (0.0182g, 0.1mmol), H2O (10mL), and NaOH (0.010g, 0.25mmol) were placed in a 25mL teflon reactor. The mixture was heated at 120°C for 3days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting orange crystalline materials were collected. Yield: 42% (based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C21H17ClN2O8Zn: C, 47.89; H, 3.23; N, 5.32. Found: C, 47.87; H, 3.21; N, 5.35%. IR (cm-1): 3382 (s), 3256 (s), 3065 (s), 1706 (m), 1629 (m), 1600 (w), 1566 (s), 1489 (s), 1446 (w), 1416 (m), 1364 (m), 1334 (m), 1311 (w), 1292 (w), 1243 (w), 1224 (m), 1127 (w), 1089 (m), 1003 (m), 820 (w), 782 (m), 735 (m) 665 (w).

Synthesis of [Cd(L)(HIP)]⋅1/2H2O (2)

A similar synthetic procedure was followed as that for 1. Here, a salt of 3CdSO4⋅8H2O (0.0256g, 0.1mmol) was used. Orange crystalline material 2 were gained. Yield: 40% (based on Cd). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C42H32Cl2N4O15Cd2: C, 44.66; H, 2.84; N, 4.96. Found: C, 44.65; H, 2.85; N, 4.98%. IR (cm-1): 3440 (s), 1669 (m), 1609 (w), 1541 (s), 1488 (s), 1442 (w), 1421 (w), 1380 (m), 1269 (m), 1241 (m), 1191 (w), 1128 (w), 1063 (m), 808 (w), 783 (m), 735 (m), 694 (w).

Synthesis of [Co1.5(L)(BTC)(CH3OH)(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (3)

A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0291g, 0.1mmol), L (0.0263g, 0.1mmol), 1,3,5-H3BTC (0.0210g, 0.1mmol), H2O (2mL), CH3OH (2ml) and NaOH (0.010g, 0.25mmol) were heated in a sealed glass tube at 85°C for 3days, then, the resulting solution was cooled to room temperature, red prism-shaped crystalline material was collected by filtration. Yield: 45% (based on Co). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C46H56Cl2N4O28Co3: C, 40.57; H, 4.12; N, 4.12. Found: C, 40.56; H, 4.14; N, 4.10%. IR (cm-1): 3286 (s), 1668 (m), 1610 (s), 1547 (s), 1489 (m), 1460 (w), 1431 (m), 1372 (s), 1285 (w), 1247 (m), 1168 (w), 1094 (w), 1069 (w), 1010 (m), 827 (w), 808 (w), 761 (m), 715 (m).

Synthesis of [Ni1.5(L)(BTC)(H2O)4]⋅3H2O (4)

A similar synthetic procedure was followed as that for 1. Here, a salt of Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (0.0249g, 0.1mmol) was used and H2HIP was replaced by H3BTC (0.0210g, 0.1mmol). The resulting green crystalline material was collected. Yield: 38% (based on Ni). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C44H42Cl2N4O30Ni3: C, 38.60; H, 4.09; N, 4.09. Found: C, 38.63; H, 4.07; N, 4.12%. IR (cm-1): 3384 (s), 1666 (m), 1611 (s), 1548 (s), 1530 (s), 1489 (s), 1461 (w), 1430 (s), 1369 (s), 1284 (w), 1246 (m), 1169 (w), 1095 (w), 1070 (w), 1009 (w), 827 (w), 812 (w), 761 (m), 718 (m).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties

The samples for solid-state luminescence of complexes 1-2 and the free ligand L have been investigated at room temperature because of their potential photoactive applications . As show in  , the L ligand displays an emission band at 312nm (λ ex =276nm), which may be ascribed to the π → π ∗ or n → π ∗ transitions . Under the same excitation conditions, the complex 1 displays a broad and strong emission at 368nm upon excitation at 273nm. For complex 2, it can be observed that emission occurs at 344nm (λ ex =271nm). Thus, compared to L, the emission maxima of 1 and 2 are red-shifted. The most likely emission mechanism is ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The fluorescent intensity of complex 1 is stronger than that of the free ligand, because of the ligand coordinated to the metal center, which enhances its rigidity and thus reduces the loss of energy through radiationless pathways . The strong fluorescence emission of complex 1 shows a potential application value in photosensitive material.

Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of coordination complexes 1-4 investigated to exhibit their thermal stabilities. As shown in  , the test for complexes 1-4 are carried out at temperature range from 30 to 800°C under an air atmosphere, For 1, the first weight loss, 5.08%, at 130-175°C is ascribed to a loss of coordinated water molecules (Calc. 3.42%). The overall framework of 1 begins to collapse at 280°C and ends 600°C with the ZnO residue of 16.13% (Calc.: 15.47%). A first weight loss of 2.11% for 2 at a region of 140-280°C is equivalent to the elimination of the one water molecule (Calc.: 1.60%). The second stage occurs between 350 and 520°C and corresponds to the release of the organic ligand. The corresponding weight losses are 75.28% (Calc. 75.64%). After 520°C, there is no further weight loss. The residues (22.61%) is CdO (Calc. 22.76%). For complex 3, the first weight loss step from 90 to 210°C is attributed to the loss of the lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules and methanol molecules. The weight loss is about 17.20% (Calc. 17.94%). A second weight loss was observed in a range of 210-550°C, corresponding to the decomposition of organic ligands L and BTC. The CoO residue of 3 of 17.73% (Calc.: 16.52%). The TG curves of complex 4 exhibit two obvious weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 14.72% at temperatures between 80 and 200°C is assigned to the elimination of the water molecules and coordinated waters (Calc.: 17.76%). The second weight loss occurred at 270°C. The NiO residue of 4 is 16.68% (Calc.: 16.38%).

decomposition temperature.type: loss of water and methanol molecules
